properties.sfomuseum:description: Interview conducted by Carol L. Osborne. Dated December 24, 1997The interview describes Captain Griffin’s experiences as a Navigator, First Officer (Copilot), and Captain (Pilot) with Pan American World Airways from 1940 to 1972; his degree in aeronautics; his work as a flight instructor with the Civilian Pilot Training (CPT) program; his training in ground school in San Francisco (Treasure Island) and in Roswell, NM; and the work he performed. He briefly describes his work on Treasure Island at the 1939 World’s Fair, and his initial flights with Pan American from that location. He discusses the aircraft he flew, including the Martin M-130; the Sikorsky S 38, S 40, S 42, and S 43; the Douglas DC 3, DC 4, and DC 6; and the Boeing 307 Stratoliner, 314, 377 Stratocruiser, 707, and 747; and the C 54.  Captain Griffin describes the short training period he underwent at Pan American and his quick advance to Copilot. He discusses his experiences while flying routes in Pan American’s Pacific Division including the San Francisco and Seattle routes to Hawaii, Alaska, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Vietnam, and Korea; the Latin American Division including the Miami routes to Rio de Janeiro, Puerto Rico, Havana, and Trinidad; the Africa Orient Division from Miami to Dakar and India; and the Atlantic Division from New York to Bermuda, the Azores, and Lisbon; and the round-the-world route. He describes the prominent figures he met, including Bob Hope, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Illona Massey.
